params.taskDescription:
When stretched out, a strand of human DNA is, on average, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>2.066</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mn>2</mn>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">2.066 \times {10^2}</annotation></semantics></math> cm. One centimeter, or 1 cm, is  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>1</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
        <mn>5</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">1 \times {10^{ - 5}}</annotation></semantics></math> km. Determine the average length of a strand of human DNA in kilometers.

params.taskDescription:
One approximation of the average number of cells in the human body is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>3</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mn>13</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">3 \times {10^{13}}</annotation></semantics></math>  cells (30 trillion!!!). If the DNA of each cell were stretched out and laid end to end, what would be the total length of the DNA in km? Use your answer from Exercise 51 for the length, in kilometers, of DNA.

params.taskDescription:
The equatorial circumference of Earth is approximately <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>4.007</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mn>4</mn>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">4.007 \times {10^4}</annotation></semantics></math>  km. Use the answer from Exercise 52 to determine the number of times that the stretched out human DNA would encircle Earth.

params.taskDescription:
The average stride length of a 1.651 m tall woman is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>6.6</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
        <mn>1</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">6.6 \times {10^{ - 1}}</annotation></semantics></math>  meters. If such a person could walk from Buffalo, NY, to Buenos Aires, Argentina, in a straight line, how many steps would that person need to take? See Exercise 18 for the distance from Buffalo, NY, to Buenos Aires, Argentina.

questionSetStimulus: For the following exercises, apply your understanding of scientific notation to real-world applications.
